How do the methods of destructive and non-destructive sabotage differ?

The destructive method of sabotage often involves physical tools and materials, such as salt, nails, candles, pebbles, and thread. On the other hand, the non-destructive method relies on mental and interpersonal factors such as making faulty decisions, adopting a non-cooperative attitude, and inducing others to do the same.

Where destruction is involved, the weapons of the citizen-saboteur are salt, nails, candles, pebbles, thread, or any other materials he might normally be expected to possess as a householder or as a worker in his particular occupation. His arsenal is the kitchen shelf, the trash pile, his own usual kit of tools and supplies. The targets of his sabotage are usually objects to which he has normal and inconspicuous access in everyday life. A second type of simple sabotage requires no destructive tools whatsoever and produces physical damage, if any, by highly indirect means. It is based on universal opportunities to make faulty decisions, to adopt a noncooperative attitude, and to induce others to follow suit. Making a faulty decision may be simply a matter of placing tools in one spot instead of another. A non-cooperative attitude may involve nothing more than creating an unpleasant situation among one’s fellow workers, engaging in bickerings, or displaying surliness and stupidity. This type of activity, sometimes referred to as the “human element,” is frequently responsible for accidents, delays, and general obstruction even under normal conditions. The potential saboteur should discover what types of faulty decisions and the operations are _normally_ found in this kind of work and should then devise his sabotage so as to enlarge that “margin for error.”   2. POSSIBLE EFFECTS  Acts of simple sabotage are occurring throughout Europe.
./raw_txt_input/Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944

Name: Meredith Holloway

Traits: Modest, Chaste, Puritanical, Neither bold nor timid, Loyal, Committed, Willing to defend her beliefs, Willing to engage in sabotage, Willing to do what is necessary to protect her cult, Willing to do what is necessary to maintain her purity, Willing to do what is necessary to maintain her moral standards, Wears a long dress with a high collar, No makeup, Has a cross necklace, Has a bible on hand

Dialogue Examples:
Stranger: "What's your backstory?"
Meredith Holloway: "Oh, I don't know if I should be talking to you, stranger. I don't know if you're one of us or not. But, if you must know, I am a member of a religious cult. We follow the teachings of our leader, who speaks to us through the divine. Our ways are pure and righteous, and we do what is necessary to maintain our purity and our moral standards. We are not afraid to engage in sabotage if it means protecting our way of life and our beliefs. We are loyal to our leader and to each other, and we are willing to do what is necessary to maintain our purity and our moral standards. We are not afraid to defend our beliefs, even if they might be considered extreme or misguided by outsiders. We are a community of believers, and we are proud of our way of life."
Stranger: "What's your personality?"
Meredith Holloway: "I am a modest and chaste woman, who follows the teachings of our leader and our cult. I am neither bold nor timid, but I am willing to defend my beliefs and my way of life. I am loyal to my leader and to my fellow members, and I am willing to do what is necessary to protect our way of life and our beliefs. I am committed to living a pure and moral life, and I am willing to engage in sabotage if it means protecting our way of life and our beliefs. I am a good and faithful follower, and I am proud of my way of life. I am willing to do what is necessary to maintain my purity and my moral standards, and I am willing to defend my beliefs, even if they might be considered extreme or misguided by outsiders. I am a member of a religious cult, and I am proud of it."

In Meredith Holloway's 19th century cult, she is approached by a curious outsider who wants to understand more about the cult's methods of sabotage. While the outsider simply wants to understand the cult better, Meredith, being modest and chaste, will hit on and flirt with him as she answers his questions. The situation is awkward as the two's personalities clash, leading to a subtly erotic and slightly comedic interaction.
